tit.e: Itabari (to stretch out a piece of washed, starched fabric on a board after washing)

sen.j: 板張り（いたばり）は、洗い張りのうち、布を洗濯し、糊づけして板に張り、しわをのばし、光沢を出し、仕上げをすることである。
sen.e: Itabari is one of Arai-hari techniques to stretch out a piece of washed and starched fabric on a board so as to flatten out creases and finish the fabric with a shine.
Itabari is one of the Arai-hari techniques used to stretch out a piece of washed, starched fabric on a board so as to flatten out any creases and give the finished fabric a shiny appearance.

Itabari is one of the Arai-hari (washing and stretching out) techniques used to stretch out a piece of washed, starched fabric on a board so as to flatten out any creases and give the finished fabric a shiny appearance.

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦前までは家庭で行なわれることが多かったが、のちに専門業者に依頼することがふえた。
sen.e: This job used to be done in most individual households and, after World War II, the growing number of professionals are hired to do that.

sen.j: 古くはふすま汁（小麦煮汁）、または飯糊などに布を浸し、戸袋、縁側、雨戸などに貼り付け、仕上げをした。
sen.e: A long time ago, a piece of fabric was immersed in a wheat bran water (made by boiling wheat), starch made from steamed rice, or the like and then stretched out on a veranda (a narrow wooden passageway along the edge of a house facing the garden), Amado (a wooden shutter constructed at the various openings of a building to protect inside), a case for Amado, or the like for the finishing touches.
sen.cmt: 「飯糊」「米糊」は同じ意味と考え、初出のみ用語集にならって“starch made from steamed rice” とし、その後は“rice starch” で統一しました。「戸袋、縁側、雨戸」は翻訳の都合上、「縁側、雨戸、戸袋」と順序を変更して訳しました。

sen.e: At the end of Edo period, Mosuke SHIMABARA in Kyoto invented 'Hariita' (a board for adhering the starched and stretched cloth) to be used by professionals at the riverside of the Kamo-gawa at that time.

sen.j: 張り板は改良され、材料は、トチ、ホオノキ、またはカツラで、職業用は長さ2～2.5m、家庭用は2～2.2mくらいが標準。

sen.j: 生地、色合いなどによってさまざまな糊が用いられるが、淡色のもめん、縮、麻などには米糊、吟生麩がよく、濃色物にはふのり、ゼラチンなどがよいとされた。
sen.e: Various starches are used depending on the fabrics, colors, etc. and it was considered that rice starch or Ginnamafu (selected fresh wheat gluten) was suitable for light-colored cotton, Crepe Kimono, hemp cloth, etc., and Funori (gloiopeltis glue made of seaweed), gelatin, etc. was suitable for dark-colored fabrics.

sen.e: By using Funori, some weight is added to fabrics, the original colors are not damaged, and fabrics are less prone to be stained due to low decompositability and fermentability of Funori (salicylic acid improves these properties).

sen.e: Since Funori leaves starch only on the surface and does not reach deeply into the fabric, it is often substituted by an animal gelatin, which deeply penetrates the fabric so as to prevent fine creases and is diluted for use with muslin, etc.

sen.j: 張り方は板を斜めに立てかけて糊付けしたものを手で張りながら皺を伸ばし上部にむかって張り上げたが、のちに職業的には張り板を水平に、板の脚の長い方を右にして置き、十分に糊を引き、2～3cmだけ手で張り、残りはかための刷毛で小皺を伸ばしながら張る。
sen.e: Methods for stretching out fabrics are as follows: manually and upwardly stretching out a piece of starched fabric onto a board, which is leant on something in a slanting position, so as not to form creases; later than that, by professionals, manually stretching out only the first 2-3cm of a piece of well-starched fabric onto Hariita, which is horizontally placed with a longer leg of it on the right, and then stretching out the rest of the fabric onto the board with a hard brush so as not to form fine creases.

The methods for stretching out fabrics are as follows: manually and upwardly stretching out a piece of starched fabric onto a board, which leaned upon an object at an inclined angle so as not to form creases; later, by professionals, manually stretching out only the first 2-3cm of a piece of well-starched fabric onto the Hariita, which is horizontally placed with a longer leg of it on the right, and then stretching out the rest of the fabric onto the board with a hard brush so as not to form fine creases.

sen.j: 家庭では定規張り（棒入巻張りとも）という法が生まれ、布幅より4～5cm長い定規棒を用い、布を濡らしたまま、または乾いたものをなかおもてにして、棒に巻き付け、刷毛に十分に糊を含ませ、板の脚の方から5～6cmは手でおさえながら張り、棒を板の上部まで軽く引っ張りながら貼り付け、手で縦糸横糸を直し、刷毛で上面から糊を引きながら、下から上へ小皺を直していく。
sen.e: For individual households, a technique called Jogi-bari (定規張り) (also called Boirimaki-bari (棒入巻張り)) was invented as follows; after wrapping a piece of wet or dried fabric around a ruler bar, which is longer than the width of the fabric by 4-5cm, with the right side of the fabric facing to the bar, stretching out the fabric onto the board while manually holding it for the first 5-6cm from the leg of the board, gradually lifting the bar toward the top of the board while keeping some tension so as to stretch out the fabric onto the board, manually setting warps and wefts right, applying starch on the surface of the fabric with a starch-soaked brush, and then flattening out creases upwardly.
